awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Old Rights, New Movements: Collective Rights and the Contemporary US Labor Movement
awd_abstract_narration:
This research investigates how existing rights are reinvigorated through "re-purposing" into new claims. The research focuses on variation in claiming and success rates by unions and other worker organizations who pursue claims under Section 7 of the National Labor Relations Act, which also applies to workers not covered under current collective bargaining agreements. Much of the existing literature has focused on the pursuit or introduction of new policies and new laws as a catalyst to greater rights claiming, whereas the current project identifies the mechanisms by which organizations transform existing policies to permit enhanced success and improved mobilization.  Moreover, in contrast to much of the existing literature, the research investigates whether institutional characteristics, including the presence or absence of specific movement-related institutions, explains the variation in claiming and success rates. As such, the current project has the potential of new insights and theoretical advance across several existing fields in socio-legal studies. 

The research plan relies on statistical analysis of case outcomes of claims brought under the National Labor Relations Act since 2000, textual analysis of associated National Labor Relations Board documents, and interviews with both worker organization staff and National Labor Relations Board officials.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to understand efforts to strengthen existing laws in the context of the "weak" U.S. state--where public officials often have limited jurisdictional authority and enforcement tools at their disposal. Despite the near impossibility of legislative reform at this time, we know little about whether and how officials can strengthen their enforcement of existing laws. This is especially true in the context of the contemporary workplace, where there is mounting evidence of increasing employer non-compliance with employment and labor laws. 

The gaps in existing scholarship on executive branch agencies are significant: Much of the scholarship of the political sociology of the state has tended to focus on the ability of newly-created executive branch agencies to enforce their mandates. Such scholarship examines the formal powers granted to agencies, their administrative resources, and whether an agency is sufficiently insulated from organized interests. In addition, many scholars of the U.S state have argued that state agencies are most able to implement their missions to the extent that certain private interests align with those of the state. Given the centrality of private actors, and especially economic enterprises, to our understanding of whether and how state laws can reach their intended beneficiaries, we have little understanding of how public officials in aged, and arguably anachronistic agencies, can expand their reach. 

Workplace law agencies are particularly important to speak to this question as they are often highly politicized and difficult to reform. Thus, many of the labor and employment laws that govern the workplace were written during periods when employment looked vastly different than it does today. Large groups of workers were concentrated within the same company, had the expectation of stable employment and even internal mobility, and were much more likely to be unionized than today's workers. 

The labor and employment laws written during the New Deal of the 1930s and the Great Society programs of the 1960s had this workplace in mind. Today, however, the number of workplaces has burgeoned and many workers labor in more contingent arrangements (e.g. franchises, subcontractors, etc.) that are several times removed from brand-name companies. Amidst growing polarization, there is little hope for reform of existing laws, even despite growing evidence that many workers are subject to illegal conditions, and have few viable routes to redress. 

In this context, I sought to examine how existing agencies can strengthen their missions even in the absence of legislative reform. To do so, I conducted interviews and analyses of agency documents to understand the efforts of officials throughout a given bureaucracy. In particular, I was interested in how officials understand their own statute, and whether they can draw on latent statutory resources to revitalize their missions. I find that interest in promoting a broader view of existing rights or laws is less partisan that the scholarship on executive branch agencies would expect, and that such interest has grown with the awareness of new social movement organizations that seek to promote workers' various rights in the workplace. Such organizations have raised the public's awareness of substandard and illegal working conditions, and some executive branch agencies have seen in them a useful platform for further educating the public. 

There is widespread internal variation within agencies with respect to the extent to which officials show interest in such efforts over both time and space. My findings suggest that they are most able to so when there is relative insulation of some parts of the bureaucracy, and when they have interactions with diverse civil society organizations. Diverse organizing infrastructures provide important outlets for outreach and learning opportunities on the part of officials. Thus, aside from shedding light on latent potential in existing laws, the project speaks to how aging laws can be strengthened even in the face of considerable constraints.

Modified by: Jessica Garrick
